com.foreach.across.config

Class IllegalConfigurationValidator

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.foreach.across.config.IllegalConfigurationValidator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AcrossBootstrapConfigurer, org.springframework.beans.factory.Aware, org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanClassLoaderAware

    @ConditionalOnProperty(value="across.configuration.validate",
                       havingValue="true",
                       matchIfMissing=true)
 @Component(value="across.illegalConfigurationValidator")
 @Import(value=com.foreach.across.config.IllegalConfigurationValidator.IllegalConfigurationDetector.class)
public class IllegalConfigurationValidator
extends Object
implements AcrossBootstrapConfigurer, org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanClassLoaderAware
    Validation class that checks wrong use of @Configuration classes, either in a module or on the application configuration level. This can be used to provide hints to the end user for standard Spring (Boot) configurations that require a different approach in an Across setup.

    Disable the configuration validation by setting the property across.configuration.validate to false.

    This validator also loads its configuration settings from the 'META-INF/across.configuration' file. The key com.foreach.across.IllegalConfiguration can list illegal entries of the form: CLASS_NAME(->MODULE_MATCHER)(:MESSAGE_KEY).

    • CLASS_NAME: name of the type that should not be present as bean (usually a `@Configuration` class)
    • MODULE_MATCHER: a format specifying how the class should be checked.

      One or more specific rules can be set, separated by a |. Any rule can be reversed by adding a !. Examples:
      • AcrossContext: can not be present on the context
      • AcrossModule: can not be present on any module
      • MODULE_NAME: can not be present on the module with MODULE_NAME
      • !AcrossContext: can be used on the context
      • !AcrossModule: can be used on any module
      • !MODULE_NAME: can be used on the module with MODULE_NAME


      If no matcher specified the type can not be used on the context level, but it can be used inside a module. As soon as a single matcher is specified, the default settings are that the type can not be used anywhere except in the rules specified.
    • MESSAGE_KEY: key to be used for looking up an additional description and action message. When a key is specified, it is expected that 'META-INF/across.configuration' contains entries of the form: com.foreach.across.IllegalConfiguration[MESSAGE_KEY].description and com.foreach.across.IllegalConfiguration[MESSAGE_KEY].description. These will be added to the thrown execption.
    Since:
    3.0.0
    Author:
    Arne Vandamme
    See Also:
    AcrossConfigurationExceptionFailureAnalyzer, AcrossConfiguration
